description.narrative: Cambodia has more than 140 registered orphanages and countless unregistered residential care centres. Only a quarter of children living in these institutions have lost their both parents. In most cases the reason for sending a child to an orphanage is pove rty and the common belief that an orphanage would provide a better future. In reality insecurity, poor governance, violence and indifference are common in orphanages, and the young people are not supported to develop life skills and social abilities. After leaving the orphanage they are likely to face unemployment, drugs, gangs, crime and sexual exploitation. They are also easy victims of human trafficking. The project implementing partner M'lup Russey promotes alternative, community based choices for resid ential care. It seeks to influence the decision makers, managers of orphanages and other stakeholders to take responsibility of monitoring and development of the child protection standards. It creates alternative working models to the orphanages and streng thens young people's life skills. M'lup Russey is one of the main partners of the Cambodian Ministry of Social Affairs in implementing child protection policies. Project activities include development of community-based child protection models, orphanage s taff training in child protection issues and supporting young people's independence, youth clubs in orphanages, support for vocational training and assistance in finding work placements, training for mentors and village-level networks, group activities to promote young people's social skills and life skills, as well as preparatory meetings for family reunification.
